title: 115_hr2574
content: The Act titled "Building a Health Care Workforce for the Future Act" authorizes grants to states for scholarship programs under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will award grants to eligible States for scholarship programs to ensure an adequate supply of various health professionals. States must submit an application to be eligible for the grant. Individuals must be full-time students to participate in the scholarship program. To participate in the scholarship program, individuals must be enrolled as full-time students in an accredited educational institution in a State offering approved courses in medicine, dentistry, nursing, pharmacy, or other health professions. They must submit an application to the State and sign a contract agreeing to accept scholarship payments. To qualify for the scholarship program, students must maintain academic standing, complete residency training, obtain state licensure, and serve in a designated shortage area for one year each year. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must demonstrate designated health professional shortage areas. When disseminating scholarship program forms, the State must include a summary of rights and liabilities. States entering contracts must clarify terms for breach consequences. The State must pay for tuition, educational expenses, and a cost-of-living stipend for individuals in the program. Consideration should be given to applicants interested in providing care services in shortage areas. Matching funds are required for States receiving grants under this section. The State must provide non-Federal contributions for scholarship program costs, administer the program directly, and submit reports on scholarships awarded and recipients to Congress. The State must report on scholarship recipients by practice area and provider type, their service in underserved communities, changes in shortage areas, remaining gaps, and the need for additional physicians. The State must report on scholarship recipients, including those who failed to comply, actions taken for non-compliance, and recommendations for program improvement. Authorization of $20,000,000 annually for scholarships, with at least 50% allocated to primary care providers. SEC. 747B. Developing effective primary care mentors and improving mentorship opportunities for medical students. The Secretary may award grants to eligible medical schools to develop and strengthen primary care mentorship programs for students. To be eligible, an entity must be an accredited medical school or college of osteopathic medicine and submit an application containing required information. The Secretary may award grants to eligible medical schools to develop and strengthen primary care mentorship programs for students. This can be achieved by incentivizing faculty to participate as mentors, providing resources for mentorship workshops, and enabling successful mentors to promote best practices at other institutions. The Secretary may award grants to medical schools to develop primary care mentorship programs for students, including offering longitudinal experiences in primary care and arranging partnerships with various organizations. The curr_chunk discusses service projects aimed at providing students with opportunities to interact with primary care mentors, offering financial resources to students working with mentors in underserved communities, and supporting practice redesign efforts led by primary care physicians. Authorization of $20,000,000 annually from 2018 to 2024 for this section. SEC. 747C. Developing and promoting new competencies. The Secretary will award grants to medical and health professions schools to promote priority competencies such as patient-centered medical homes, chronic disease management, mental health care integration, public health integration, cultural competency, and domestic violence. The Secretary may award grants to programs providing education for various healthcare professionals, with consideration given to partnerships with other medical programs. Grantees must submit reports within 180 days of grant completion. The Advisory Committee must receive a report within 180 days after the grant period, detailing the use of funding, intended goals, challenges faced, and lessons learned by the grantee. The Committee will then provide recommendations to the Secretary based on this information, focusing on scaling up innovations for healthcare provider education and training. The authorization of $10,000,000 for fiscal years 2018 through 2022 is allocated for training healthcare providers in priority competencies. SEC. 4. STUDY ON DOCUMENTATION REQUIREMENTS FOR COGNITIVE SERVICES. The Institute of Medicine will conduct a study on documentation requirements for cognitive services under Medicare, Medicaid, and private health insurers. The study will evaluate modifications needed for electronic records, the impact on physicians and patient care, administrative costs, and time required for documentation. The Institute of Medicine will conduct a study on documentation requirements for cognitive services under Medicare, Medicaid, and private health insurers. This study will focus on options to compensate physicians for patient care without excessive documentation and recommend less burdensome alternatives for existing documentation requirements.
